Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged
Hi Nnamdi, thanks for the patch! I have a couple of comments and a query about the address validation, but otherwise the functionality is definitely something we should merge.
Hello Andrew, thank you for the comments. I agree with all of them, and have pushed a new change to that effect.

Hmm, I'd probably pick a different name for this. Really it's the offset into the basic management command response. I think a name like `NVME_MI_BASIC_OFFSET` would be an improvement.

That said it's also not a change that's required by this patch. Do you mind dropping it for now?
Done
I agree that it is not a change required by this patch. I shall be dropping it.
Assigning to a variable isn't necessary, if we really needed to we could just supply the macro to the function invocation below. But I think we just drop the macro and leave the constant 0 there?
Done
I also agree with this. I shall drop the macro and leave the constant as 0.

We probably *do* want a name for this magic 0x08 number. Are you basing this on the SMBus spec? Because there's a whole bunch of other address values that it shouldn't take either.

So, I think either we don't worry about checking this, or we get a bit more specific about what it is we're actually trying to check.
Done
I based 0x08 off the starting point of a 7-bit address. Considering that there's a bunch of other address values that it should not take, I lean more towards not bothering to check it.

I think we can remove this line from the commit message, because as it stands the patch now never introduces the macro to begin with. Leaving this statement in feels pretty confusing if you're unaware of the history of the patch.
Thanks for pointing it out. I have amended the commit.

Hi Nnamdi, the next hurdle is that I don't think Cloudflare has signed a corporate CLA. Is this something you can get addressed? I'm following up with Brad to see if he's aware of one.

Generally once we have a CCLA with your name on it you get added to a group in Gerrit which automatically enables CI runs for your user. The fact that CI didn't trigger is what made me follow up :)

More information on CLAs here:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#starting-out
Hello Andrew, Cloudflare has signed the corporate CLA, and it has been approved by Brad. Please what do you advice has the next steps.

Can you please add some details about why this is needed?  nvme-mi I thought explicitly specified the slave address;  Are there devices in the wild that disobey that?  Can we get some documentation around the option that it's for non-compliant devices?

Hello Ed, you are right about nvme-mi explicitly specifying the slave address (0x6A), however, the SSD form factor such as that seen on Intel P4000 series SSDs uses a different slave address (see nvme_p4000.json, https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/configurations/nvme_p4000.json). I shall update the documentation that it is for non-compliant NVME Interface devices, as you have suggested.
You need to pick a default that matches the old behavior, otherwise you're breaking everyone else.
Thanks for the catch. I shall set the default slave address to use the old address.
Sorry for the delayed responses. I did not realize my responses were just in draft and not published all these while.
One minor cleanup suggested, the code as-is isn't incorrect though. Otherwise this looks good.
Hello Andrew, thank you for the suggestions, I have done the cleanup and updated the commit.
I don't think we want the return value to be `std::optional` as we return either the specified value in the EM configuration xor `NVME_MI_DEFAULT_SLAVE_ADDR`, and never `std::nullopt`.
Thanks for this, I have made the change to return `uint8_t`
If we remove the optional above we don't have to test this here.
I have removed the test.
Hello Andrew, I have cleaned the code as suggested.
When referencing code within this repository, please use relative references like: configurations/nvme_p4000.json
Noted. Thanks. Refactored to use a relative reference. Do not that this reference refers to Entity Manager project which is outside this repository.
Please wrap it up to 72 chars, as per commit msg guidelines.
Thanks for the catch. Fixed in the new patchset.
Looks good, only one minor comment
nit : You can change magic number to sensor->offset.
Magic number (ie 0x00) was there before, and isn't new in this commit.
As already mentioned by Ed, 0x00 was not introduced by this commit.

Keeping this var public means this can be edited in code. 
It is recommended to keep the variable as private and providing a getter function to get value of the variable.

> Keeping this var public means this can be edited in code. 

This is already true of bus above it.  Keeping code consistent is arguably more important than following the rules in this case.

> It is recommended to keep the variable as private and providing a getter function to get value of the variable.

If we're going to be technical about this, the test we should be passing is:

https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/checks/misc/non-private-member-variables-in-classes.html

But this class already doesn't pass that test, so I'd rather we keep consistent.  If the author wants to move both bus and address to private members, accessible by methods, that's fine, but I don't think we should require it.
As Ed mentioned, this was done for consistency. A separate patch can be created to use a getter function to get the values of bus and address across dbus-sensors.
nit : better to treat this const or const expression ...?
Agreed. Thanks for the catch. This has been changed in the new patchset.
MACRO is not typesafe as mentioned in line number 26  better to treat this const or const expression .
Agreed. Fixed in new commit.
Thank you for the constructive feedback. The suggestions have been implemented in a new commit.
Thank you for the feedback. The suggestion has been implemented in the new commit.
